newsitem.title: USA: KLM, Northwest seal billion dollar peace pact.
newsitem.headline: KLM, Northwest seal billion dollar peace pact.

text.p: Northwest Airlines said Wednesday it agreed to buy back a 19 percent stake in the company from KLM Royal Dutch Airlines for $1 billion in a deal meant to strengthen their often stormy alliance.
KLM will sell back its holding to Northwest for four annual payments totalling $1.07 billion to $1.17 billion in exchange for a long-term cooperation pact.

The deal, hailed by industry analysts as a welcome resolution to the airlines' lengthy boardroom battle over control of Northwest, could create "the most far-reaching airline alliance ever seen," the carriers said in a statement.
Northwest stock soared on the news, gaining $3.125 to $41.25 on Nasdaq.

The airlines said the new marketing and operational alliance was for 10 years and could be extended to include new partners. KLM also agreed to drop a lawsuit against Northwest that stemmed from a dispute over its ownership stake.

The carriers set one of the first global airline alliances, a practice that has become widespread between U.S.-based and foreign carriers. The alliance allows them to coordinate flights and to funnel passengers, for example, from Northwest's domestic routes into KLM's European service.
"Theirs was basically the first alliance and so far-reaching, they had no choice but to patch up their differences," BT Securities analyst Vivian Lee added.
Officials at the two airlines said the new pact should help the partnership.

"Removing the ownership dispute from the relationship will only enhance our partnership," said Northwest's director of international communications, Douglas Killian. The new pact was reached after 3-1/2 years of talks, he said, noting Northwest will make the payments from cash reserves.
Killian said the operating alliance has added about $50 million to Northwest's annual operating income, an amount that could increase to $65 million this year.
He said the two carriers may integrate their cargo operations. "There is a lot of potential to work together," he added.
In Europe, analysts said that KLM's top priority now was to seek a European partner.
"The most important thing now is to pick up a European partner to boost their market share to the targeted 15 percent," said Frits de Vries, airlines analyst with Gilissen Bankiers.
He said KLM's decision to go ahead with Northwest ruled out the likelihood of a link-up with British Airways, currently awaiting European Union approval for its mega-alliance with American Airlines.
Instead, KLM would likely seek ties with Italy's Alitalia, Northwest's preferred European partnership candidate, he said.
Alitalia also has a strong position in Latin America, a blank spot in Northwest's route network, he added.
The Italian carrier's state holding company said earlier this week that KLM was at the top of its list for an alliance with the financially troubled carrier.
But KLM itself was tight-lipped on potential candidates.

"We never call names in that respect but the intention of both partners is to expand their alliances with other partners ... to come to a global airline system," KLM spokesman Peter Wellhuener told Reuters Financial Television.
While the partnership -- the first-ever trans-Atlantic alliance to gain U.S. antitrust immunity -- has flourished at the level of operations, boardroom relations have been frosty.
The two airlines have bickered for several years, with KLM taking the U.S. carrier to court over a plan that prevented KLM from further boosting its stake.
Northwest has repeatedly charged KLM with seeking to take it over and said the Dutch carrier was a "creeping control threat."
